title: Why it's not possible to set WebGLCubeRenderTarget.texture as texture (map) for Material ?
author: bytesbay

comments.body:
> The strange thing is if i use for example envMap - everything works without error.

When you are using an instance of `WebGLCubeRenderTarget`, its texture property is an instance of `CubeTexture`. Using a `CubeTexture` in a shader requires a `samplerCube` uniform type and `gl.TEXTURE_CUBE_MAP` as a binding point target. The `map` property uses `sampler2D` uniform type and thus requires `gl.TEXTURE_2D`. 

So in other words you can't use cube textures as 2D textures in the shader and vice versa.

@Mugen87  Thanks for your reply!
So, there is no way to use `WebGLCubeRenderTarget.texture` as a `map` ? 
Maybe there are some conversion methods ?
Or the only way is writing custom shader?
Unfortunately, you can't sample a cube map like a normal texture. A conversion does not seem sense to make either since the special layout of cube textures require a specific sampling.

title: Why don't we add material properties to InstancedMesh so that materials can vary over instances? Is it gonna hurt performance?
body:
I am impressed by what InstancedMesh can do in the aspect of performance.
But I also find it difficult and messy to manage different instance meshes on same geometry because of some material property differences.

I saw some examples which add some properties(ie: color) to solve this problem.
Then why don't we add most material properties(of MeshPhysicalMaterial) to InstancedMesh so that materials can vary over instances?

Is it gonna hurt performance in any way?
author: bianyunzhi95

comments.body: Per-instance color has been added recently, see `setColorAt(index, color)`. GPU instancing does not allow per-instance textures, and there's a limit to how many scalar/vector/color properties can be used as instance properties... more could be added in the future, but I think we'd need to prioritize specific properties that are helpful rather than trying to include them all. Custom shaders or NodeMaterial will provide you more options beyond that.

Thank you.
So is it ok to add other properties but textures? like metalness, roughness etc. Can this break limit on number of instance properties?
And how would it affect the performance?

It shouldn't affect performance, but this sounds pretty complicated to support — and avoid hitting vertex attribute limits — to me. The upcoming work on WebGPURenderer will use NodeMaterial as its primary material system, which handles these things pretty well. So that's where I think we should invest most development time, and new properties for InstancedMesh before then should probably be justified on a case-by-case basis.

I think of instancing as being used for things like trees, grass, and buildings. Those might differ with different shades, but not usually different metalness... do you have examples where these specific properties are important to vary with instancing?

I am building sth like editor/viewer so there isn't a specific property. I would like to know if adding 6-7 attributes might break that limit or not in case I add them using custom shaders. Thank you.

The limit is a bit complicated. You can expect at least 16 vertex or instance attributes to be supported, and more on some devices. three.js requires:

- 1 vertex attribute for each vertex attribute used by the mesh: position, uv, uv2, normal, tangent, color, skinWeights, skinIndex, ...
- 4 instance attributes (?) for the instance transform
- 1 instance attribute for each other per-instance property, such as color.
- 1-8 vertex attributes for morph targets

So depending on your input model, you might have >11 attributes still available, or none at all.
Ok. Got it. Thank you very much.

title: GLTFLoader: Alpha mode should default to Blend when material color has transparency
body:
##### Description of the problem
Some software exports GLTFs without setting alpha mode, even in materials with transparency. Blender correctly renders these materials as transparent, but the GLTFLoader defaults to opaque even when an alpha < 1.0 is specified in the material.

##### Suggested solution
When alpha < 1.0, if no `alphaMode` is specified, default to `BLEND` rather than `OPAQUE`.
author: diegoescala

comments.body: The glTF specification is pretty specific that when alphaMode=OPAQUE, any transparency in the baseColorTexture or baseColorFactor must be ignored by implementations. I think it would be necessary to report bugs to software exporting alpha < 1, without setting alpha mode. Do you have an example?
Yes, OnShape does not appear to be setting the flag when exporting.

>When alpha < 1.0, if no alphaMode is specified, default to BLEND rather than OPAQUE.

According to glTF spec 2.0, the `alphaMode` property specifies how alpha is interpreted -- not the other way around.

Also, `alphaMode` is not required, and defaults to `OPAQUE`.

Thanks. Sounds like the implementation in the loader conforms to the spec then. I fail to see the logic behind defaulting to opaque when a material is clearly transparent, but that is a question for a different forum.

>I fail to see the logic behind defaulting to opaque when a material is clearly transparent

It is not always so clear. Transparency can be set in the alpha channel of the texture. The loader is not expected to discern that.
Yes, good point.

SimplifyModifier routine and always get a crash.  There are a couple points in the code that say can be optimized, but i am not exactly sure how to do that. comments.body:
Geometry modifiers perform in general topological operations on data. Using a format geometry representation like `BufferGeometry` which is optimized for rendering is usually no good approach. Using `Geometry` makes the code more manageable but also more ressource-intensive. 

You might get better results with a different type of implementation (e.g. base on half-edge data structure) but I assume it won't be easy to implement if you want to support processing 10 Mio. faces.

title: r72 essentially kills Geometry and harnessing of GPU through GLSL
body:
I'm getting the error `THREE.ShaderMaterial: attributes should now be defined in THREE.BufferGeometry instead.` because my shader material is trying to access attributes.

I decide to try and change code to use `BufferGeometry` but then, as per documentation:

> This class is an efficient alternative to Geometry, because it stores all data, including vertex positions, face indices, normals, colors, UVs, and custom attributes within buffers; this reduces the cost of passing all this data to the GPU. This also makes BufferGeometry harder to work with than Geometry...
> 
> ...This makes BufferGeometry best-suited for static objects where you don't need to manipulate the geometry much after instantiating it.

This change in r72 does not play well with the usage we've been giving Three.js at the projects I'm overseeing! 

The projects I use Three.js in are built for mobile app environments, we want to **force** GPU usage, **NOT** `reduce the cost of passing all this data to the GPU`.

I've even been focusing on writing articles about this sort of usage in the past months and advocating using Three.js because it allowed (up to r71) to force GPU usage. 

Also countless guides on how to use shaders in Three.js are adamant about using as much GPU as possible to handle geometry transformations, and now all this content is invalidated.

Why you would want to take vertex positions and color data away from GPU is beyond comprehension, _that's_ what the GPU is there for.

Please, bring back the power of the GPU.
author: jeanlescure

comments.body:
I think you misunderstood the quoted text. Both `Geometry` and `BufferGeometry` use the GPU. The difference is that `BufferGeometry` structure is ready to be uploaded to the GPU.

The cost of passing the data to the GPU refer to using less CPU and Memory, which is what happens when we render `Geometry`.

title: Possible feature request - render list sorting
body:
Hi guys

I have written an octree in threejs and i've been testing it in a pretty big scene. It works nicely enough but there doesn't seem to be any marked difference. 

From my research I can see that three uses a flat list when doing its rendering. I can see that for each item it checks its visibility and then does the frustum calculations. 

In the octree I developed I am setting the objects visibility property to false if its out of the frustum and so if the camera is looking at a corner of the scene outwards, the other half / two-thirds are not visible. My thoughts were that this would cut out a lot of the render calculations etc...

This doesn't actually seem to improve the speed though... The time to render stays pretty much the same whether the octree is on or off (Even though I can see its set half the scene to not visible ). 

I was wondering if this is because the render list is flat. Perhaps by adding some functionality to allow us to take out big chunks of the rendering pipeline it might speed up the scene somewhat? 

Just wanted to know hear your thoughts on it.

Thanks guys
Mat
author: MKHenson

comments.body:
GPUs are super fast these days on modern PCs.  I suspect you are not taxing the GPU at all.  It is just a bunch of simple draw calls unless you are doing simulation or something.

I think that if you have a very large outdoor scene, it makes sense to cull a lot but if you are just reducing 50% of your draw calls and you don't have a ton to begin with, it isn't much of a benefit.

Game engines show different levels of details based on how close they are to the camera.  They also use distance culling a lot in outdoor scenes, especially to control what you are loading.  Reducing the amount of data loaded makes a big difference because a level may not actually fit into GPU memory.

I think if you can cut draw calls by 90% of really detailed scenes, octree-based culling will seem more useful.

But generally people don't use octrees for culling small scenes, there just isn't enough benefit.

Hi Bhouston

Yeah, I actually am trying to create an outdoor scene. I've gone about it by making a large number of terrain tiles and placing them next to each other as separate meshes. I did try to brute force render it as one large mesh but it did struggle quite a bit; so instead I chopped it up into many smaller tiles. I figured creating an octree would then help to reduce the calls to which objects need to be drawn. I just tested it again, but this time with a really really large scene, and I do see an improvement in using the Octree - but its still not ideal. It definitely feels a bit laggy. 

I think what I'll do is expose the ''renderList' variable in the render process and see if handing over only the visible objects helps it a bit. 

Thanks

Be sure to use the Google Chrome profiler and also possibly an NVIDIA GPU profiler to see where the time is being taken.  Also I'd calculate the percentage of culling you are doing -- and I would strive for a really high number.

Doing profiling and getting hard numbers is incredibly important.

Check out previous discussions about octrees - #2148 #3001 

I guess it probably depends on your scene and implementation, but octrees should potentially should be able to speed up object picking and collision detection too.
I want to try and use the BufferedGeometry to see if it speeds up the application, but it doesn't seem to work with picking... Don't think I can use it if that's the case.

title: Changing geometry properties after creation
body:
Hello,

I've found that for me it may be very convenient to change geometries creation properties after creation (it is impossible for now). For example:

``` javascript
var g = new THREE.PlaneGeometry(100, 100); // create geometry
g.width = 200; // modifying width property
```

Do you have any plans/considerations about such api?

Thank you,
Ostap.
author: ostap1010

comments.body:
The different geometries create all the vertices and faces etc at construction time and generally don't preserve the parameters. Modifying a construction property afterwards would effectively mean recreating everything, which is expensive and as thus it is not wise to hide it under that kind of API (which could falsely lead a user think it's a cheap operation), nor it's worth to complicate the code by that IMO.

That being said, modifying a thing like width can be achieved by applying a matrix transformation (e.g. in this case creating a x-scaling matrix and calling `geometry.applyMatrix(scaleMatrix)`). This will modify the vertices. If you need to do that in real-time, the `scale` property of `THREE.Mesh` can be used.

title: THREE.Ray.intersectObject  does not take into account the rotation of the mesh when delivering face.normal
author: ironbane

comments.body:
That is by design. 

The face is dependant on the geometry. So that means it never has a rotation applied on its own.
It is only the mesh that has that geometry that has possibly a rotation applied. 

The reason for this design is normall for certain reasons:
- A geometry can be used for multiple meshes which could have different rotations.
- A geometry is now cheap in computation becuase it is static. So we don't have to do a lot of calculations.

Unfortunately no. Sorting is always done just inside a single particle system. This is a intentional design for getting a good performance (each particle system is a single fixed size buffer object).

You can try to use different tricks to see if you can't get acceptable results - `alphaTest`, turning on/off `depthTest` / `depthWrite`, different blending options.

title: Want to change the height of a cube mesh

I have been able to change the height of a cube geometry mesh by using mesh.scale.y however this is unsatisfactory as i only want to increase it upwards or downwards but when I scale it it changes uniformly in both directions upwards and downwards. author: akshaysrin

comments.body: Thanks a lot

For anyone stumbling upon this now, a little clarification.

`mesh.scale.y += delta` changes the scale of the mesh, so if the scale is 1 and you add 1, the mesh doubles. 

`mesh.translateY()` moves the mesh by a physical distance. So if the y value of the mesh is 5 pixels, adding 1 moves it to 6. 

Instead of `translateY(delta/2)`, you should figure out how much the `mesh.scale.y += delta` physically increases/decreases the mesh, then you should translate by half that amount.

title: renderBufferImmediate vs renderBufferDirect (for indexed draw)
body:
HI Guys,

i was wondering what is the difference between renderBufferDirect and renderBufferImmediate?

i see that marching cubes is using renderBufferImmediate, but it also only seems to support vertex and normal buffers. i have a custom version of marching cubes here, but it also has index buffer, texture and color buffers, and immediate doesnt seem to support it. 

should immediate be enhanced or should I use Buffer direct, and would there be a performance penalty?

thanks!
author: Huck

comments.body:
> i see that marching cubes is using renderBufferImmediate, but it also only seems to support vertex and normal buffers. i have a custom version of marching cubes here, but it also has index buffer, texture and color buffers, and immediate doesnt seem to support it.

As of last week, `ImmediateRenderObject` supports texture coordinates and vertex colors (see #1834).

> i was wondering what is the difference between renderBufferDirect and renderBufferImmediate?

`ImmediateRenderObject` (this is what's rendered via `renderBufferImmediate`) is best suited for rendering objects with  variable number of triangles. 

You create fixed size typed array buffers for each attribute. Your object gets a callback and then it's up to you to keep filling the buffers with data till there are triangles to render and call this callback to render unindexed triangles (`gl.drawArrays`).

This is used for `MarchingCubes`.

`BufferGeometry` (this is what's rendered via `renderBufferDirect`) is best suited for rendering large static geometries. You create one huge typed array buffer per attribute and store offsets into JS array. Then renderer renders these as indexed triangles (`gl.drawElements`), moving attribute pointers according to offsets.

This is used for CTM models.

thanks for that, thats great.

title: Questions about the use of Gamma Correction in the WebGL Renderer
author: WestLangley

comments.body:
> Is it best to assume that texture images are gamma-corrected, and therefore a good idea to always set
> renderer.gammaInput = true;
> renderer.gammaOutput = true;

Yes, this should be the most common case (if you want to have linear color space shading and your assets are in gamma space).

> Does it ever make sense to have one true and the other false? (I suppose it does, otherwise they wouldn't be separate settings, but I can't think of such a case.)

Yes, you could have your assets already in linear space (in: `false`, out: `true`) or if you want to do also postprocessing in linear space, then you would keep the output in linear space (in: `true`, out: `false`) and do gamma correction manually just at the end of postprocessing chain.

> What if there are no texture images involved in the application? Should these parameters be true, anyway?

As you prefer. Again this depends on the whole asset pipeline and rendering pipeline and what "look" do you want to have. It doesn't matter if textures are involved or not, material colors themselves can be in linear or gamma space.

> If gamma renderer.gammaInput = true, then should you always convert shader colors like so? (It's not always done in this way in the examples when renderer.gammaInput = true.)

It depends on in which color space you will author the content. 

If you already work in linear space, no need for conversion (that's probably what happens in these examples, colors tweaked already in the browser WYSIWYG). 

If you get assets that were created in gamma space, then you would need to do the conversion.

This whole topic is somehow messy and inprecise, as in many cases we don't know how the assets were created. If you would create bigger project from scratch, then you would need to take care that everything is set up consistently. 

I think modern games try to do everything in linear space, their content creation tools work in linear space and output linear space data, engine does everything in linear space and just at the very end it applies gamma correction.

If you just use random content from the web, most likely it was authored in gamma space and you need to convert it into linear space before shading.

pow(source, vec3(gamma)) would suffice?

_If you just use random content from the web, most likely it was authored in gamma space and *_you need to convert it into linear space before shading.***

setting

will do that conversion?

``` javascript
object.geometry.dynamic = true;
```

`dynamic` flag tells renderer to keep its internal typed array buffers used to create WebGL objects. These are otherwise thrown away after transferring data to GPU so it doesn't matter which value this flag has afterwards.

We do this to avoid wasting memory for static objects (while keeping performance for dynamic ones).

title: Scene scaling
body:
Hi there,

I'm rather new to it though and I've got a question concerning the scaling of the scene: I couldn't find a scale or the equivalent of the GL_MODELVIEW matrix property in the scene or the camera, and was wondering how I could perform the equivalent of a glScalef to change the scale of all a scene's objects at once. author: Maxweel

comments.body:
Add a dummy `object3D` to the scene, and then add the remaining objects as children of the dummy object. Then scale the dummy object like so:

```
dummy.scale.set( 2, 2, 2 );
```

Make sure the camera is a child of the scene, and not a child of the dummy object.

author: Tobiasartz

> Does this count for the textures that WebGLRenderTarget creates as well?

Yes.

> Also, how dramatically do odd sized textures affect the rendering performance. I haven't really noticed a difference in FPS when I switched to POT dimensions.

Like with everything, you need to have use case where particular thing becomes bottleneck. In this case it's dealing with lots and/or big textures.

Most notable example was ro.me where for video textures this made a big difference, especially when combining several of them. Also I remember virtual online gallery which was noticeably slower with lots of NPOT textures.

Though even if you don't get bad performance, you may still want to have POT textures to be able to have mipmaps and nicer filtering (with NPOT you can have just `nearest` and `linear` filters).

title: Get rotation angle from PerspectiveCamera w/RollControls
body:
Hello,

Apologies if this seems obvious but I'm new to Three.js and 3D maths in general.

I'm using RollControls with a standard PerspectiveCamera in my 3D WebGL scene.  I want to be able to get the rotation angle(s) of the camera.

I have tried querying camera.rotation, but it always returns (0,0,0) - presumably because RollControls uses matrices to perform the rotations and movement.

What is the best practice for getting x, y, and z rotation angles for the camera in this case?
author: njmcode

comments.body:
```
rotation.setRotationFromMatrix( camera.matrix )
```

The solutions are not unique, however, so beware. That is, in the reverse direction, there are multiple rotation combinations that yield the same matrix.

Consequently, in the forward direction, it is possible for a small change in the matrix to yield a very different rotation vector.
If all you want is the heading, you should be able to infer that from the `RollControls.forward` vector.

I'm afraid I have no idea how I would do that.  The `RollControls.forward` vector has the following values for each of the cardinal directions (assume a flat travel surface with an 'upright' Y axis and no pitch - think Doom here):

```
    x   y   z

N   0   0   1
E  -1   0   0
S   0   0  -1
W   1   0   0
```

Given the odd way these numbers scale when rotating around the Y axis (which is always 0, as I've said), I really have no idea how I could convert this to a degree angle between 0 and 360.  Apologies again for my lack of understanding, I really appreciate the help.

The function you need to use is Math.atan2(z, x), which will give you an angle in radians that you can convert to degrees. You will then need to handle each quadrant separately in order to convert those degrees to the correct bearing from North. It will be a little tricky, but you'll only really learn it if you figure it out yourself. ;-)

title: three.js security
body: I didnt test it yet but i am wondering if would be possible to change three.js objects such as removing a mesh by means of javascript injection. For instance, if i make a scene with walls maybe someone can remove a mesh with javascript injection?
author: danieljack

comments.body:
You can always fit your code inside a closure

``` javascript
( function () { ... } )()
```

and your code shouldn't be able to get easily injected.

It's possible to set a breakpoint on a line of code (using Firebug or Chrome's dev tools) and run commands via console at that point in the code; this would allow someone to inject values inside of a closure.

Best defensive against people manipulating your code/values: minify + obfuscate. There is no 100% solid, hackproof method. If someone wants to change something bad enough, they will. If it's important, you should have some sort of communication with a server where you can validate all values (first person shooters do this, if you remove all the walls in your game client you can't just walk through them as the server validates your position).
Yes, server side checking collisions is the only safe way, though not sure how to check collisions in real time for a fps in server side

You can use WebSockets to connect the browser to a server and check on the server (run three.js in node.js, for instance).

I saw a great article on how games (older and modern) use ensure everyone is seeing the same thing but I can't find it now. Basically the client keeps a record of movements/changes it generates (player walks, turns, shoots) and sends those to the server. The server checks everything and sends those commands to all clients. As a command is received by a client it coordinates the command with it's own local changes (based on timestamp) and replays all local changes which haven't been server-processed yet.

Obviously, the level of event-security you need depends on what you're doing. In Call of Duty it is vital to keep track of "Player 1 shot before Player 2 did" and replay the events accordingly. Other applications are less sensitive.

Ugh, I'm on my phone, not computer, and missed @matthoz last post. Yes, that is the correct way to do it :)
If we recalculate the normals and vertices, what does __dirtyNormals = true; do?

The WebGLRenderer caches some geometry attributes such as vertice positions, normals, tangents, etc (there are seven I believe) - if you modify one of these then you must tell the renderer that it needs to update its cache by marking the __dirty\* flag as true.

The __dirty\* properties are WebGLRenderer specific, while the compute_Normals methods aren't. If you use the CanvasRenderer then there is no need to use the __dirty_ flags and setting them are just wasted cpu time and memory.
Ok! One last question: are there situations when using WebGL where you would call computeFaceNormals() and computeVertexNormals() but _not_ set __dirtyNormals = true; ?
None that I can think of, unless you don't want to display the updated normals right away for some reason.
Hmm, then I'm still confused... What does __dirtyNormals=true do what oGeo.computeFaceNormals(); and oGeo.computeVertexNormals(); do not?
The compute-methods seem to recalculate the stuff and with __dirty\* vars you tell the renderer to put the recalculated stuff into the buffer again. At least I think it works like this.

Ah ok, and it won't do that automatically to make it possible to recalculate the geometry without yet sending it to the GPU. And setting __dirtyNormals = true; is only needed for WebGLRenderer, since CanvasRenderer obviously does not use any VBOs.
Yep, it's necessary for WebGL only, as chandler explained yesterday.
Yeah, I was thinking of an explanation why it was the way that Chandler indicated and you provided that explanation :)

If you happen to be needing this, be aware that __dirtyVertices and __dirtyNormals
have been renamed to 
_verticesNeedUpdate_ and _normalsNeedUpdate_

title: about loaders and materials
body:
Hi all!
im exporting a scene from blender using the blender python script and i have some questions about how material loading is implemented. 
Im my test case, I have a scene file with some meshes in separated files (like the blender scene in the examples)
I've been debugging sceneLoader.js and loader.js code and i see that the way three.js loads materials is something like this:
1. SceneLoader loads the materials defined in the scene file and puts them in Result.Materials. These materials are default materials (depending on the material type) plus some (usually few) new properties.
2. For each geometry, Loader.js loads the materials inside the file. These materials (in the blender exporter case) have more properties than the ones loaded in the scene file, but have the same names (in my case)
3. For each model in the scene file, it uses the referenced geometry (loaded from the geometry file) and the material FROM THE SCENE FILE, so the geometry material is not used. I also noticed that most of the scene's material properties are created from default values and not exported from the original materials (these values are correct in the geometry file),

So the questions are these:
1. Why materials from geometry files are not used? I guess a model instance could use a different material...
2. If this is correct, blender exporter should create more complex material files in scene file, is this correct?

One solution could be to have a material on geometry file and the material in scene file could modify some of the properties of this 'geometry material'

I dont know if Im missing something...  I think the relation between materials in geometries an scenes is not very clear...

Thank you!
author: Gazzell

comments.body:
Yeah, it's somehow convoluted, asset pipelines are pain, you don't really have one-to-one correspondence between various formats and tools.

Materials from individual JSON model files are used when meshes in Blender use multiple materials (then `Mesh` on three.js side uses `MeshFaceMaterial`). 

When each model in Blender is a separate mesh with a single material then scene materials are used (and thus these materials can be shared between multiple meshes). 

So which material will be used depends on how your scene / models are constructed.

Thanx for the comment.
I think that materials should be used allways the same way (in the scene file), independently of if they are normal or multi material. Perhaps exporters should break meshes with multi materials in independent meshes, or perhaps a better solution could be insert a 'model' class just over 'mesh' so a model could have multimple meshes with only one material per mesh.
Having only one material per mesh could improve the way meshes are orderer for optimizing GL state changes....
This is a common problem in 3d engines :-S

These are just a few ideas, perhaps not the best ones :-)
Yep, some people suggested that an it made me think about it a bit. It involves quite a lot of changes so it will take some time to test it and consider it...

I kinda experimented with something in this direction for CTM based models, as there it was the only option for having multiple materials per model. It works but it's more pain to deal with.

Though this is mostly question of asset pipeline, internally we anyway have to split everything into single material triangle batches, that's how OpenGL ES works. 

And sorting is tricky in any case, you have different things you could sort for, often conflicting - transparency, depth, shader, buffers. Plus sorting itself in JavaScript brings non-trivial overhead.

I plan to eventually look closer into this, just this is non-trivial thing. I know there can be big performance differences, tricky part is how not to screw some use cases when improving other ones.

For the moment, deep guts of `WebGLRenderer` are constructed in a way that if you don't do silly things when constructing the scene (like alternating geometries / materials), it should mostly work quite close to optimal performance (very little unnecessary stuff sent to GL).

title: What are material { DbgColor, DbgIndex, DbgName } for ?
body:
Examples and issue threads have been useful for working out how to construct a three json file. However, I'm not sure about these attributes of a material:

```
"DbgColor" : Always seem to be set to "15658734" in examples

"DbgName" : Just a name, does it need to be unique?
```

I guess it would help if I know what "Dbg" stood for.
author: ArgentiApparatus

comments.body:
`Dbg` => `Debug`

This is mainly for checking for how the conversion from some other format went, to see correspondences and have fallbacks for edge cases.

Debug colors are there as fallback if there was some mess with materials in the original data (if asset pipeline cannot figure out original material color, it'll give unique debug color to such material).

Index is help to see immediately which position in the array material has when looking at JSON file (e.g. if you want to access material by index and don't want to count).

Name is not necessarily unique, again as original data can be messy, it just reflects what was in the original data (if there was something).

title: CanvasRenderer got slower?
body:
After quite some time I went through all the examples and found some canvas examples noticeably slower:

```
canvas_camera_orthographic2.html
```

Hmmm, `canvas_camera_orthographic2.html` is new. When is "before" more or less?

Particles got slower when they started using `ParticleCanvasMaterial`. `canvas_lights_pointlights_smooth.html` got slower since Chrome added antialiasing to the `context.clip()`. Overall I haven't noticed any slowdown, at least not because code changes.

This new ortho camera example used to be completely fluid when I have checked it just after it got added. Now it's crawling at ~10-15 fps. Maybe before it was using `WebGLRenderer`? Or maybe it started with some different parameters, other views after clicking are much faster.

For other examples "before" may be several weeks.

Particles I don't remember when I checked the last time, though I think it was already with this new material. I think wavy example used to be like 50-60 fps, now it's at 27-33 fps.

Also `canvas_particles_sprites.html` used to be completely fluid, now it crawls at 9 fps.

Stuff that used magic trick for shading used to be not crazy fast but still somehow ok, now examples with "smooth shading"  are incredibly slow.

But you probably know better, you are more familiar with canvas examples.

Also, I just checked live examples on GitHub (that use old `r45`) and they are also slow so it kinda suggests slowdown caused by Chrome change.

In general, I had quite bad experience with 2d canvas performance evolution - a lot of my old non-tree.js demos got either slower or completely broken in several browsers over the course of the last year. 

I tried to look into this and it seems culprit is switch to GPU acceleration for 2d canvas - some use cases got really bad.

> > I wanted to ask is there any way to add 4 directional lights in a scene?

Yes, directional lights shouldn't be problem, it's point lights that are very limited.

Just turn up `maxLights` parameter in `WebGLRenderer` constructor:

``` javascript

```

Though @mrdoob is currently doing some changes about how lights are handled, if you are using his `dev` branch, I think `Scene` there doesn't have `lights` array so probably everything is broken there right now.

@alteredq Indeed, `dev` is pretty broken right now, working on it tonight. The way I'm doing it is that `Projector` is giving back a list of lights and a list of objects that need to be rendered. So it'll be similar to how it was before. Oh, and I removed the matrixRotation calculation out of `matrixUpdate()` (only needed in Canvasrenderer) which improved quite a bit webgl performance examples ^^
Cool cool. Hopefully we'll be able to make it without driving garbage collector crazy.
The `array.length = 0` trick was good enough me thinks, and the flexibility/simplicity this system offers is just too good :)

If there are no problems on performance examples then I guess for regular use it should be fine. 

Did you test also on Firefox? Chrome handles some degree of garbage collection pretty well, it's mostly just Firefox that chokes even with just a small amount of memory trashing (at least on Windows). 

Well, we'll see, if there'll be too bad effects, we could maybe do never shrinking arrays, like currently in `WebGLRenderer`.
4 directional lights works in firefox only not in chrome.Is this going to be fixed?
What is the problem with having more than 4 lights? Are point lights just processor intensive and a limitation on hardware?

Well, it's kinda complicated. 4 used to be safe limit not to blow over maximum varyings allowed by ANGLE / DirectX 9 when all other material features were turned on. 

But now we have more material features and different ways of doing shading so it may be possible to have both more or less lights depending on circumstances (which types of lights and which material features are on).

So if you want to have more lights, you can try, it may work, though bear in mind lights are expensive (independently of varyings constraint).

title: Attach object to surface on vertex-shaded mesh
body: This is not an issue with the engine really, it's more of a question. Is it possible to sync a objects movement with a mesh that has been manipulated through a vertex shader? I have an ocean and wants a floating boat on it's surface. The mesh has a sin-function applied for animated waves. I'm trying to use the same offset-function on the boat, but it wont stick. I just guessing, is it because the vertex-shader changes the vertices from the modelView-perspective and not object-space? Is there a better  way to find the surface-position for any given xz-point?
author: inear

comments.body:
> I just guessing, is it because the vertex-shader changes the vertices from the modelView-perspective and not object-space? 

I guess it depends where you apply your displacement - `position` attribute is in object space. 

If you add offset to it before multiplying with `modelViewMatrix`, it should correspond to adding offset to `geometry.vertices[x].position` (this is before applying object transform to get absolute world position).

If you want to access world-space position in vertex shader (untainted from camera), you could skip supplied `modelViewMatrix` and use instead separate `objectMatrix` and `viewMatrix`.

This:

``` glsl
vec4 mvPosition = modelViewMatrix * vec4( position, 1.0 );
gl_Position = projectionMatrix * mvPosition;
```

Is equivalent to this:

``` glsl
vec4 mPosition = objectMatrix * vec4( position, 1.0 ); // world space
vec4 mvPosition = viewMatrix * mPosition;
gl_Position = projectionMatrix * mvPosition;
```

Thank you @alteredq for helping out so quick! I managed to get the boat floating by changing modelViewMatrix to viewMatrix and set that later, as you said. I finally gained some real world understanding about those matrix transformations.

author: krychu

These uniform types use just straightforward JavaScript arrays (also Typed Arrays should work).

So for your example something like this:

``` javascript
uniforms = { "cps": { type: "fv", value: [ 30, 30, 0, 100, 30, 0 ] } };
```

For access in shader like this:

``` glsl
uniform vec3[2];
```

``` javascript
uniforms = { "cps": { type: "fv1", value: [ 30, 30, 0, 100, 30, 0 ] } };
```

If you want to access it in shader like this:

``` glsl
uniform float[6];
```

title: texture loading/binding error
author: larsberg

comments.body:
Hmmm, I was able to reproduce this behavior (just with a bit different error messages).

Problems is actually not about textures but about using shared geometry for two objects which require different GL buffers because they use materials with different complexities - `MeshLambertMaterial` requires normals (for lighting), `MeshBasicMaterial` does not.

Buffers are lazy initialized on the first use, so when you render as the first one object with more complex material, normals buffer will exist in shared geometry (and it'll not bother object with less complex material later on). But if you do the opposite render order, second object will be missing normals buffer.

Workarounds are: 
1. be careful about order of creation / initialization to have most complex materials first or 
2. use non-shared geometries for objects which have materials requiring different buffers (besides lit/unlit it's also for example smooth / flat normals).

Thanks alteredq! that clears everything up for me. Looking back on it, I should've guessed it was an issue with with attributes/buffers and not textures. I guess moving forward I'll avoid sharing geometry between materials. 
cheers, Lars

title: Performance question (individual meshes vs merged)
body:
Dear all,

so here's what I'm trying to do:
- I have 700~800 meshes, each with about 40 faces
- each mesh has a different texture (256x256px png image)

I'm trying two cases:
(1) add each mesh individually, with its own material (MeshBasicMaterial with texture map) 
(2) create each geometry and set the material in the Face4s. Then merge all geometries using GeometryUtils.merge

I would expect (2) to perform much better than (1), but it is much worse... Is this due to the fact that the geometry is split into geometrygroups depending on material? I'm looking to extend this to a large number of meshes (1500~2000) and would expect to need them to be merged all into one mesh for performance reasons? The material is essentially the same program across all faces, except for the texture used...

If I merge all the meshes, would it make sense to also merge the different textures somehow (on a canvas?) and index this large texture (but how)?

UPDATE: I've been looking at this from a Javascript profiler perspective, and it seems the biggest culprit is the repeated updateObject calls which iterates over all geometrygroups of the merged mesh to see if anything needs to be done. When I instrument this function to only be evaluated once, performance improves quite a bit (but not enough). Now (1) and (2) seem to be on par at about 30 frames per second. I guess that this basically now boils down to doing the same things: rendering every mesh, or rendering every geometrygroup... One option would be to bypass all the program updates, except for the texture buffer (or go with a mega-texture)?

thanks for any pointers!
kind regards.
author: NINE78

comments.body:
This is tough, state changes are expensive - a lot of simple things will have much worse performance than few complex things.

The closest to what you try to achieve is minecraft AO example, though even this was simpler (much less and much smaller textures). 

What I did there was to merge textures into one big texture in 2d canvas (texture atlas as you put it in other issue) and merge geometries by `GeometryUtils.merge` and then create custom UVs to map faces into this big texture.

So there was just a single geometry buffer, single texture and single shader for everything.

title: Distance in PointLight
body: I'm just wondering how does the distance parameter in pointlight work. Setting anything above 0 seems to turn off the light and any greater negative values doesn't not seem to change the lighting settings..
author: zz85

comments.body:
`Distance` controls linear attenuation of `PointLight`. 

If it's zero then attenuation is switched off and light affects all geometry. If it's `>0` then it tells at which distance from the light vertices get zero light. 

Attenuation is linear so vertices just next to light get full light, vertices half the distance get half the light and vertices at and beyond distance get zero light.

title: Why some entities share the same code?

author: vatula

comments.body:
Yep, this will work on that case.

But if you were hacking some code on your app and you wanted to make sure you were doing stuff with Face3s your code will have to look like this:

```
if ( face instanceof Face3 && !(face instanceof Face4) )
```

instead of just this:

```
if ( face instanceof Face3 )
```
Hey, you already have this (for Camera)! :) Why not use it for THREE.Face[x]?

Why not just use a Facebase class, from which both Face3 and Face4 extend?

That way, instanceof will still work like a charm...

But what's the problem of having these 2 structures? I understand they are almost identical, but I don't see what's the problem of having them like that. Does it create any issues interacting with the API? or is it just for optimisation purposes?

It's always good practice to don't repeat yourself (less code, less prone to errors, better portable) and extending/cascading helps to make clear how the Object-tree is structured. The former DRY principle of course is most important when you have large repeated codechunks.

Still, I would not use extending here, since the repeated code is very little, and it scatters the code around in extra classes.

But that's just an opinion :-)

Only for optimization and aesthetics. I saw a couple of places where functionality is copied where it is logically to have a subtype (less code, faster loading time, code is less prone to errors, blah, blah, blah). Also I aim to create a GWT wrapper for three.js and it is much easier when there’s Java-like subclassing :)

comments.body:
There were quite a few changes recently in model format / `Loader`. 

From the snippet you posted it looks like your model is still in the old format (property names with underscores, now they are CamelCased). So if you updated `Loader`, old model it will not work.

You can try to reconvert it with the latest OBJ converter.
Ah, good answer...that did the trick.
Is there a trick to lighting with this type of object? No lights seem to have any effect.

Lights are not yet exported, so you'll need to add them in the application manually. 

Also model needs to have proper normals. If they are not exported, face normals should be computed automatically after loading. 

If you want to compute also vertex normals, you should call `geometry.computeVertexNormals` on the geometry you get from the loader (though these automatic normals may differ from normals in the original model, thus is you want smooth normals, you should export them).

Finally make sure you use `MeshLambertMaterial` or `MeshPhongMaterial`, only these use lighting, `MeshBasicMaterial` does not. 

Though this shouldn't be issue if you take materials from the model loaded via `Loader` (i.e. `MeshFaceMaterial`), only if you override materials yourself.

title: why are GPU buffered objects still slow to render?
body:
As far as I understand, objects are bufferend on the GPU once they are created (using gl.createBuffer() etc). Thus, once all elements are created, I would say that there is no pushing of elements to the GPU anymore, but only telling how they have changed (right?). 

Still though, when I draw 10.000 cubes on the screen once, and do not change the objectmatrix in any way, I only get < 1 fps with webGL. How come? 

I would argue (with my limited knowledge) that after the first push to the GPU, the rendering would speed up greatly, as the objects don't have to be changed after that point. One could simply tell the GPU: draw your buffers onto the screen, et voila! Or does it not work like that?
author: fabricasapiens

comments.body:
The matrices get calculated per object whether they change or not... you can try doing `mesh.autoUpdateMatrix = false;` and `updateMatrix()` whenever you need them to update and see if that speeds up things...

There are a few other optimisations that could be done right in the Renderer now you mention...

It does make a 30% difference or so. When I have 900 objects, the fps rises from 7 to 10. When I have 10.000 objects, the fps stays below 1 ;-)

Is it really impossible to not send any information to the GPU when the object has not changed at all?
I don't really know...
I will try to figure it out...

I've found the bottle neck to be the setUniform, you're pushing at least 10.000 16 float transform matrices to the card every frame and it's quite slow with JS at the moment, making state sorting that much more important, unfortunately not much use in this case :-( You could try creating a new material for each cube so the uniforms only have to be set when they're updated but that would probably be a huge memory drain and it would take ages to compile that many shaders. There are a few other options but they get progressively more complicated to implement.

Hmm, that's a pity.

The thing is that I thought/hoped that it would be possible to **not** push all those matrices to the GPU, because they didn't change. In other words: why can't the GPU just keep rendering all its buffered objects until they change?

It is possible on modern hardware but webgl doesn't support it yet. There was talk a while ago about including in webgl v1.0 (even some early demos using it) but I believe it was decided to leave it out for now. I'd suspect it's going to be among the first extensions so might be here in the next few months, at least in the nightlies, fingers crossed ;-)

Kinda hard typing with all my fingers crossed, but if that is what it takes to get it implemented ;-) 
Seriously though, I really hope that it gets implemented! I see why it was postponed though, because it is only an issue when there are thousands of objects to be streamed to the GPU. 
Anyways, let's just wait for this feature, or for faster streaming! :-)
